verses.text: Do not rejoice, Israel, as other peoples do; for you have been unfaithful, leaving your God. You love the wages of a prostitute at every threshing floor.
verses.comment: Israel’s joy is false because it comes from unfaithfulness. Threshing floors were places for celebration, but now are tainted by spiritual adultery—Israel seeking reward apart from God.

verses.text: Threshing floor and winepress will not feed them; the new wine will fail them.
verses.comment: Their idolatry leads to famine and deprivation, showing how sin breaks God’s blessing on creation. Echoes God removing sustenance as a just consequence.

verses.text: They shall not remain in the LORD’s land; Ephraim shall return to Egypt, and in Assyria they shall eat unclean food.
verses.comment: Exile is the penalty for apostasy. Egypt and Assyria represent bondage and uncleanness, echoing the Exodus motif but in reverse—spiritual separation from the land initially given by God.

verses.text: They shall not pour out wine offerings to the LORD, nor will their sacrifices please Him; their bread will be like mourner’s bread—all who eat it will be defiled—because their bread will only satisfy hunger and will not come into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Rituals done apart from God’s presence are empty. Bread consumed in mourning is unclean, drawing on liturgical purity and the importance of properly ordered worship—pointing to the ongoing necessity of reverent worship.

verses.text: What will you do on the day of appointed festival, and on the day of the LORD’s feast?
verses.comment: Israel’s loss of communion with God makes their worship powerless, foreshadowing how being away from God’s presence makes celebration hollow.

verses.text: For behold, they are going away from destruction; Egypt shall gather them, Memphis will bury them. Their treasures of silver shall be overgrown with thorns; thistles will cover their tents.
verses.comment: Egypt and Memphis—centers of idolatry—will not save them. Even material wealth is lost, recalling Genesis curses where thorns overtake the land, a symbol for sin’s consequences.

verses.text: The days of punishment have come; the days of requital have arrived; Israel shall know it. The prophet is considered a fool, the man of the Spirit is insane, because of the abundance of your sin and the great enmity.
verses.comment: Israel’s rejection of true prophecy leads to confusion. True guidance is scoffed at, but judgment reveals who has spoken truth. Prophets were often rejected but are vindicated in judgment.

verses.text: Ephraim is a watchman with my God—but the prophet’s snare is on every path; enmity is found in the house of his God.
verses.comment: The prophet’s role as a spiritual watchman is corrupted by opposition and danger. Even the house of God faces hostility, alluding to divisions even within sacred worship.

verses.text: They have sunk deep into corruption as in the days of Gibeah; He will remember their wickedness, He will punish their sins.
verses.comment: Reference to Gibeah (Judges 19) signals extreme depravity and culpability, highlighting Israel’s need for purification and the surety of divine justice.

verses.text: Like grapes in the wilderness, I found Israel. Like the first fruit on the fig tree, in its beginning, I saw your ancestors; but they came to Baal-peor and consecrated themselves to shame, and became as detestable as the object of their love.
verses.comment: Israel was chosen and cherished, but idolatry at Baal-peor made them corrupt, prefiguring the need for re-consecration to God (cf. spiritual renewal through worship and sacraments).

verses.text: Ephraim’s glory will fly away like a bird—no birth, no pregnancy, no conception.
verses.comment: Loss of fruitfulness is a direct result of turning from God, a recurring Biblical motif linked with spiritual sterility until true restoration comes.

verses.text: Even if they raise children, I will deprive them, so none are left. Woe to them when I turn away from them!
verses.comment: Echoes covenant curses (Deut. 28)—God’s just response to persistent rebellion. The tone anticipates hope of future restoration through divine mercy.

verses.text: Ephraim, as I have seen, was like Tyre, planted in a pleasant place; but Ephraim will bring out his children to the murderer.
verses.comment: Being planted like Tyre alludes to a privileged position, squandered through rebellion. The reference to children links back to consequences for future generations when faithfulness is rejected.

verses.text: Give them, O LORD—what will You give? Give them a womb that miscarries and breasts that are dry.
verses.comment: The prophet intercedes, yet only judgment comes forth—emphasizing barren consequences as a sign of lost covenant blessing. Reflects the seriousness of Israel’s separation from divine favor.

verses.text: All their evil began at Gilgal; there I came to hate them. Because of their wicked deeds, I will drive them out of my house. I will love them no more; all their rulers are rebellious.
verses.comment: Gilgal was a place of covenant but became a place of rejection. ‘My house’ refers to the sanctuary—the loss of worship is emphasized, underscoring the gravity of division from true spiritual authority and worship.

verses.text: Ephraim is stricken; their root is dried up; they shall bear no fruit. Even if they give birth, I will kill their cherished offspring.
verses.comment: The dried root symbolizes a broken spiritual heritage (Jer. 17:13). The theme of death versus fruitfulness points toward a longing for restored life, fulfilled in Christ (John 15:1–8).

verses.text: My God will reject them because they have not listened to Him; they shall wander among the nations.
verses.comment: Exile is the tragic outcome for refusing God’s voice. Wandering points to loss of spiritual identity and the need for a gathered, faithful people under true divine guidance, anticipating a future universal restoration as seen in messianic prophecy (cf. Is. 11:12).
